38445277.review:
This game is super fun and for me has run flawlessly since getting it on Steam.

I'll say now though, you can very easily tell that this game is from 2003. The graphics have NOT aged well. 

That said, the creature creation aspect is a blast. Mildly annoying at times if you are concerned with making your army well-balanced, but also a great puzzle as you constantly try new combinations.

It's one of the only games where you can really build your own army from the ground up. The only games that I can think of that are anything like that are the games in the Earth series, but this feels more unique than that, though admitedly less complex of a game overall.

It's been a while since I've touched the campaign, and I haven't played it since I got this game again on Steam, but I remember it fondly.

For ten dollars, this is a game that's worth grabbing to experience the joy of making some Impossible Creatures.

Also, devs, if you're seeing this... sequel when, please? This is a concept that deserves one. So much potential with modern technology.

35927882.review:
Коротко:

Это плохая стратегия с простым, но интересным сюжетом и ровно одной классной идеей - из двух разных животных комбинируем себе юнита.


Развернуто:

Да это шаблонная история про "таинственное" исчезновение/убийство отца, с ВНЕЗАПНЫМ поворотом сюжета в конце, и с одними из самых стереотипичных в мире злодеев: коварного "цель оправдывает средства" бывшего военного, бугая "я тупой, но исполнительный" помощника и горбатого профессора (по-моему, горбатый ученый это как фермер с гладкими и нежными руками).

Но подача, субъективно конечно, приятная. Стереотипы кажутся осознанной пародией сбежавшей из фильмов про Остина Пауэрса, при этом разыгранной без лишних кривляний и с хорошо подобранными голосами.

Ядром же игры является возможность скрещивать животных, получая при этом нелепых, но вполне боеспособных товарищей. Бегемот с богомолом? Легко - будет большой и толстый юнит с дополнительной парой передних конечностей. Слон и сова? Запросто - будет всей своей тушей падать на врагов с небес.
Менять кстати можно каждую отдельную часть тела: голову, передние и задние конечности, тело, хвост.

По-моему это была отличная идея для того, чтобы игра стала хитом.


Почему не вышло? Потому, что разбилась идея "вдребезги" о реализацию.

Как стратегия и тактика игра не работает совсем. Комбинируй, не комбинируй, добавляй "хитрые" св-ва вроде "ядовитый", "регенерация" и прочие - все бесполезно. Все в итоге сводится к простому пушу и простейшему правилу: "кто толще, тот и прав". Плюс "воздух" не работает - слишком легко контрится.


В итоге стоит траты драгоценного времени? 

Ради необычной задумки взглянуть стоит, может компанию пройти. В конце концов, если даже 8-bit Armies находит игроков - вот вам, пожалуйста, геймплейно похожий пуш, к тому же с сюжетом. ;)

34563594.review:
Before I get stuck into it, I should say that you [i]must[/i] install the mod Tellurian. Vanilla IC is unbalanced as all heck. Tellurian is amazingly balanced and [i]still[/i] being updated.

This game is perhaps the oddest RTS I’ve ever seen. The defining feature of IC is that you can [i]create your own units[/i]. In the singleplayer campaign you can edit units on the fly but in skirmish and MP battles you have to pick an “army” consisting of nine units – which isn’t enough to cover all the roles that you can make, so you have to do some prioritising.

The unit creation consists of combining one creature with another and selecting which bodypart of which you want for the stats. You can’t combine three creatures, only two. But there’s more to this than just raw statistics – there are also quite a lot of special abilities. Some of these are passive (e.g. Horns, which reduces enemy defense, Poison Tip, which reduces enemy attack…), and some are triggered (e.g. Stink Cloud, Infest, Electric Burst…). These special abilities are not OP enough to mean that they’re how the game is run, but they’re also not so weak such that they’re not worth it.

Some nuances of the creature editor: [list]
[*]Combining a Size 1 with a Size 5 animal will always result in a Size 5 animal – even if you have no bodyparts of the Size 5 animal.
[*]Stats scale based on size so that’s why a giant porcupine is more deadly (& more expensive) than a small porcupine
[*] Combining two ranged attacks does nothing but combining two melee attacks means they stack – 10 melee head damage + 10 melee tail damage = 20 damage total
[*]The creature’s overall strength determines its tier level[/list]

Now, I mentioned the Tellurian mod. I only got IC about a year ago, where Tellurian (usually just called “Tel”) had been the norm for quite some time. It was still being edited, adding a couple more creatures, adjusting existing ones, and upping the tier times considerably. Before Tellurian came out this game had been played [i]to death[/i] by those that stuck with it (the game was released in 2003) and as such the optimal combination for [i]everything[/i] was known.  As well as how stupidly OP some things were (lobsters, anti-air towers, hovering spam, barrier destroy, the really low Tier V upgrade cost...) Now that Tellurian’s come along with new stuff there’s new strats to try, new creatures to combine, and generally new things to do.

Oh, and Tellurian was nearly included with the Steam version by default. The reason it wasn’t is because this would make it more difficult to update (source: lost to time so not [b]that[/b] reliable, but hey – it is very balanced and pretty much nobody plays without it)

As was said, for MP battles / non-campaign SP you can pick nine creatures to run with. Or swim with, or fly with – this RTS is one of the few to have a functional flying class. In fact, it has the oddest classing system I’ve ever seen:[list]
[*]Melee 
[*]Ranged – beats Melee and Fliers
[*]Artillery – attacks with an area of effect, beats ranged
[*]Sonic – beats anything bunched
[*]Fliers – can only be attacked by ranged or artillery units[list]
[*]Melee Fliers
[*]Ranged Fliers – generally not worth it as they’re more expensive
[*]Artillery Fliers – somewhat broken as they counter ranged units which counter them so it becomes a spam-war[/list]
[*]Amphibious combinations of any of the above[/list]
And then of course you can start putting on special abilities – eg fliers with Electric Burst, such that you run in with ten crummy HP units and click Burst right above all the enemy henchemen! Or melee with Stink Cloud such that you can’t be shot at with ranged units. There’s also two types of stealth so you can use those too (upon attacking they become visible for ten seconds, so a lack of stealth detection isn’t a disaster)

More ways in which this is a thoroughly odd RTS:[list]
[*]One resource is solely generated (Electricity) and the other resource is solely mined (Coal), and the mined resource has a maximum rate per coal pile at which it can be mined (the recommended is 2 henchmen per coal pile)
[*]Units train extraordinarily quickly – as such a game that goes on for an hour is quite long.
[*]Rushing in Tier II (with Tel) is balanced
[*]Tier II / Tier III units are thoroughly useless lategame unless they have some useful special ability. Unlike, say, AOE2, when you can upgrade Militia through to Champions, you can only get some generic “increased HP/attack/line of sight/etc” upgrades and as such you’ll just ignore your T2 / T3 units when you’re in Tier V (the final tier).
[*]The equivalent of your “Town Center” is your lab. You cannot build a second lab and if it is destroyed you are out of the game (fortunately it has pretty high HP as well as some special abilities of its own).
[*]Defensive towers are pretty trash for their price (though the standard tower does have stealth detection…)
[*]Walls are [i]extremely[/i] trash and barely worth the micro to build (heck, there aren’t even any gates!) [/list]

On the whole this game is about map control – securing the bonus coal piles for a faster gather rate, holding Geysers for more electricity, whacking your opponent’s expansions, etc. It’s not so much about individual unit-to-unit fighting – instead, it’s about fighting for control of the map. If your enemy holds two thirds of the map and you hold one third he will be able to train twice the creatures you can – granted, with some clever micro and cunning unit selection & strats you can still survive or even win.


Anyway, enough on the actual game and now what I think of it. 

It’s amazing. It’s one half of the RTS I’ve dreamed about. (The other half is Medieval II: Total War, where you take a Grand Campaign and fight [i]all[/i] the battles (if you like) in an RTS fashion.) Impossible Creatures is extremely unique. I’ve never seen any other RTS in which you can create your own units and as outlined above the uniqueness of IC doesn’t stop there. The campaign is [i]extremely[/i] cliché, but it’s not bad level design (most of the time), a good introduction into IC, and worth playing no more than twice. The AI is okay but not great & has some abuse tricks of its own (though the only reason it’s a challenge is because on Hard and Expert it just cheats in bucketloads of resources). 

The multiplayer community is very much alive and kicking. Not frequent, and if you enter the lobby randomly the chance is about 60% that there will be no-one else there. But they’re still around and most of the organisation happens on their Discord (just make a post on the forum discussions asking “where’s the MP community at.”) On the whole they’re all pretty nice people, despite their tendency to spam “xddddddd” – funny that, the smaller the community [i]usually[/i] the nicer it is. Certainly they’re helpful and prompt with their tech support (which 50% of the time is “read the FAQ” xddddd).

This game certainly isn’t for everyone – if you’re up for a more traditional RTS go get AOE2 retail (not HD, that’s a mess) but the unit creation is both a novel and interesting idea that has been very well balanced in Tellurian. But it’s certainly for me :D 


[i]One[/i] last word: there’s not much of a reason to get the Steam edition when you can get [url=https://www.gog.com/game/impossible_creatures]the GOG version[/url]. The Steam edition has workshop support (but you can install mods manually) and standard Steamworks functionality, but the GOG version has famously no DRM so you can run a LAN party on all your machines at once. Oh, and this is one of the games that basically goes on a 75% off sale whenever due to being so old so you can snaffle it when it’s cheap on both GOG and Steam and get the best of both worlds.

Its actually really good, completley functional despite its age. The interface doesnt feel clunky and the controls are simple and effective. The only thing that really shows this game's age is the art and sound but it still gets all the important aspects right as everything is identifiable. The workers voice lines can be very obnoxious so I'd reccomend turning them down so that it doesnt detract from what this game does really great.

I would compare the in-match gameplay to be similar to Warcraft or Starcraft, but definately a lot less complex as there's only one faction with an average number of different buildings that can be placed (About 14) and a max of 9 unit types for each army. The complexity in the game mostly come from the building of that 9 unit army, as there's TONS of different unit variations that actually make huge impacts on the gameplay. The game actually has a huge ammount of depth through this system and it inspires a lot of creativity. 

I've only encountered a few graphical bugs in the army creator that hurt nothing and one cumbersome issue. Certain vrsions of Windows make multiplayer in this game more difficult but you just have to go reenable a legacy setting that windows started disableing by default called Direct play. The fix for Win10 is listed below

Not many people seem to play the multiplayer but its not completely dead, I would definately recomending buying it with friends (especcially when its on sale)

 On Windows 10 go to "apps and features" -> "Programs and features" -> "Turn Windows Features on or off" -> "Then make sure Legacy Components" has a checkmark and then open it and inside will be "Direct Play" which also needs to be enabled with a check mark.

31944147.review:
Ah man, where do I even start with IC. I suppose the first thing I should say is that I own a hard copy of the original game, bought during 2001 or so. I can't really remember why I wanted the game as I was just a kid; I guess I saw some really weird creatures on the front and thought "I want to play that game". Probably one of the best gut decisions I've ever made in regards to video games. I used to play this constantly as a kid, and even after growing up I'd still take a few hours here and there testing a new combination or playing a match. It wasn't until last year that I stopped due to my new computer not being able to play IC after an update. Fast forward to the end of the year and I, a new Steam user, happened to stumble upon this game once more.
Impossible Creatures is, as the Steam tags say, a RTS game through and through. However, it's a bit more complicated than that. As most of the game's page will point out, the units you control are all from your own design. Want a flying elephant? Just mix it with an owl. That not working out? Why not switch the elephant with a sperm whale? There 30-40+ animals for you to mix in match in this RTS to make the perfect 9 unit army. And if the base animal count isn't enough for you, there's plenty of mods out there for you to try and plenty of people to try these new creatures out on. Surprisingly, there's a lot of people still playing this game despite it being well over 10 years old, and thanks to Steam having a working online server, multiplayer battles are possible. Battles are pretty fluid, though perhaps a bit simple with more or less "throw your units in certain directions", but there's many ways to make a battle more interesting. If I were to summarize the game in general in 3 words, they'd be: simple, fun, and imaginative.
So I've been saying a lot of good about the game, but what's bad you might be asking. Well...not a lot, to be honest. The graphics are a bit dated (though they should be, this is an old game) but they don't look terribly bad. There's not much for solo play, but there is a single player mode and the base game has a short story mode which is nice. Also the units are a bit prone to lagging out (like they will take long pauses before doing something) if you have a lot of units in the world, but that's only in more extreme situations. Probably the biggest turn-off about the game is that not every unit is made equal; certain combinations are obviously better than others, but to an extent that makes sense. That isn't to say some unique combinations won't get you far and that tactics don't mean anything, but having certain combinations will definitely present you with an edge to the fight.
So what do I think about it? Certainly, it's a unique game in the RTS genre and certainly worth its price of $10. I recommend it to everyone. It's simple to pick-up and play, but you're really only limited in your ability to think up a creative way to solve a problem. And trust me there's many ways to solve problems here. This is a great game, and I (maybe foolishly) hope for the day I see Impossible Creatures 2 in development.

EDIT: Oh yeah, I also forgot. This game comes with a side component called "Mission Editor" (referred to as Impossible Creature Editor on Steam). What does this do? It allows you to make your own maps for your playing pleasure! And it's a surprisingly modern world editor for being 15+ years old. Everything molds smoothly (well, unless you literally make a pointed mountain), objects are well organized, various methods to edit the terrain aside from standard increase/decrease/smoothing tools...it's really good! The only thing I don't like about it is that you have to paint cliffs...no seriously, if you make a mountain, you need to put on mountain side textures to make it look different than the rest of the terrain (that said, I'm lazy so I don't want to do that).

So let's review; with this game, you get: a pretty good standalone RTS game with a unique feature (which is dated mind you, but still really good), a map editor for free for said game, free DLC automatically downloaded into the game, additional user-made "DLC" on Steam or online, online multiplayer...There's not much bad! And for $10 (and this edit was made when there was a sale, so that $10 is even lower!)! One note of caution though, this is a RTS game and thus suffers from standard RTS problems (some things are always better than othersfor example), but the unique "build-your-team" element more than makes up for that if you learn and understand how to counter certain units. That said, once again, this is a game well worth it's price.

31650714.review:
I am a huge C&C Generals fan for many reasons. Generals provided a different way of playing RTS with less foucs on micromanagement and more focus on pummping out troops and getting into the actions asap.....

Impossible Creatures follows this formula but with a twist! Frankensteining 2 creatures into a new unit! Want to mix a Elephant with a Ant? DONE! Want to mix a Praying Mantis with a Coyote? DONE! The list goes on and on! 

This unique feature to the game gives the player hundreds of thousands of combinations that will customise your strategy and give you total freedom on how you want to play the game! 

Combining two creatures doesnt just enhance the looks of the unit, but planning is also required as each creature has its own unique stats. Being able to replace certain parts of a unit can enhance a specific stat. Size in this game doesnt matter! Even the smaller, cheaper units has their place in battle! Ive played around in the Army Builder portion of the game and it gives you the felxibility to create your units ahead of time and save them to play at a later date.
 The options are endless and I have already went back several times to retweak or replace units to give my ever changing strategy a boost or the ability to run with a new strategy.....If you think combining two of the best units in game will give you the advantage....think again! Everything is balanced to a way that even cheaper units can get the jump on tougher units as well.....you pay one way or the other when trying to make super units or just trying to invade with cheaper units....a balance is required and gives you the freedom to make those balances yourself!

The only drawbacks I can see with this game atm is it needs a serious remaster done to it! The game is absolutely fun and unique if you are a RTS fan....and even if you arent, it can easily draw in those with a more creative style of play.
The other is multiplayer based games. But, There is a Impossible Creatures Online group you can join herein Steam to get matches going. Its a pretty good size community and with lots of helpful players. 
I havent yet touched the Campaign portion of the game, I hear it maybe a little weak but still fun.

All in all, it was the best $10 I had spent on Steam thus far! Pick it up, play less than 2 hours and if you dont like it,  return it. What do you have to lose by doing that?

I owned a disc version of Impossible Creatures before, so I have more hours in the game than Steam shows.

Impossible Creatures is an odd RTS that might not have the best core RTS mechanics but compensates wonderfully for it with a very interesting unit designing mechanic. Especially in the campaign where you can switch your creature composition on the fly (whereas in skirmish you have a pre-designed army of 9 creatures that you can make in that match), the odd composite creatures that can be created keep the game fresh. The campaign also has a very pulp adventure feel in it, which fits the aesthetics of the game well.

The skirmish is not as interesting since you will be locked to using the creatures you designed before the match rather than adapting on the fly. It does make the armies of different players vastly different though, which will be a unique challenge compared to most other RTS games.

Pour moi, c'est l'un des jeux des plus originales et des plus jouisiffe auquels j'ai pu joué dans ma vie de joueur.

Ce jeu à pour moi un concept, certes, qui peut sembler bizarre à première vue, mais qui est enrichisant au possible: on y prends plusieurs animaux, de toutes sortes , pour les "combiner" (les mélanger) pour en faire une créature unique. Donc à vous de faire le petit scientifique à mélanger des animaux et à créer des créatures des plus bizarres. 

Mais le jeu ne s'arrête pas là, après s'être marré à combiner et à créer des choses de plus en plus bizarre pour ensuite les engeristrer, la partie commence et le but est d'envahir la base de l'ennemie avec les créatures que vous avez crée juste avant. Mais attention! Ce ne sera pas si facile, l'ennemi a aussi des créatures des plus étranges à vous faire découvrir....


De plus, le jeu propose un mode solo sympathique avec une difficulté croissante (la première partie est d'une facillité déconcertante et la dernière partie du jeu est très dur), un mode multijoueur, et une gestion des mods sympathique rajoutant régulièrement des nouvelles cartes et es nouveaux animaux pour toujours plus de combinaisons!!

Un jeu que je vous conseille surtout pour son originialité, ces multiples choix et stratégies (des animaux qui ont parfois des attributs uniques, et surtout des nouvelles  armées et unités  que l'on peut créer à l'infini et jamais ressemblante) , et son gameplay accrocheur ( que deux ressources à collecter dans le jeu, ce qui facilite la prise en main du jeu).

Et, vus  son prix minime vus le nombre de possibilités disponibles, je vous le conseille d'urgence!!!!!


Note: 9,5/10 (j'enlève 0,5 points pour ces graphismes qui ont assez mal vieillit et le travail de restauration du jeu de steam pas exceptionelle)

29329119.review:
It's a pretty fun little game! It's in line with other RTS' like Age of Mythology, so if that's your thing, then you're guaranteed to have at least a little bit of fun with this game (since so many RTS' are so alike). 

Pros
-----

- Graphics are charming despite being dated.
- Game runs perfectly fine on low end PC's.
- Music sounds fine (RTS' aren't exactly known for their soundtracks anyways). 
- Making your own units is fun and done in an amusing way. Unique for the RTS genre. 
- Workshop adds some fun to the game. 
- Amusing campaign and such.
- Voice overs for the characters are nice. 
- Seemingly a good while of content to keep you amused. 

Cons
------

- Dated graphics (hardly a con). 
- Workshop quite literally only has one popular mod. 
- Failing a mission means you have to restart, which is tedious for 30 minute missions.

Overall the game is really nice for a cheap sale purchase. The one problem though is the unit customization, which is a shame when it's the selling point of the game. While cool, it feels a bit stale. You tend to combine similar groups of animals and/or class types (tank, scout, offensive types) together all the time. It works by combining certain swappable parts of animals together which in turn provides you effects (kick attack for legs versus claw attack for clawed arms) or abilities based on the used parts of the certain animals. The problem lies in the fact that you're basically using 90% of one animal but only 10% of the other, as opposed to a 50/50 split to produce something crazy. If you need a fast creature, you're probably going to combine two fast creatures with slight differences together to try to make the most optimal fast creature. Combining anything else may give you another ability to use, but the stats on the animal will be weakly split in to two countering stats, which feels worse than just having that "super fast cheetah / wolf mix that deals more damage while still being super fast." For example, you could combine that cheetah with that wolf to give it more damage while still being super fast, or you could combine that cheetah with that skunk to gain the skunk ability, but at the cost of all of the good stats either of them may/may not have, which feels worse than the optimal cheetah / wolf mix. 

That all being said, the game's fine. It's an old game, and as an old game, it was made beautifully. Worth the cheap 3 bucks I spent on it.

29309768.review:
AMAZING GAME, but the port to Steam hasn't been handled particularly well.

TLDR; gameplay is on-par with any modern RTS, graphics are decent enough for gameplay, but understandbly show their age during cutscenes, and the Steam port still has some bugs to work out. 8/10, but if you have it already you should definitely wait for a sale, it's not worth the full price just for online play (Hamachi does it well enough).

Impossible Creatures places you at the helm of either your army of heroic eagle-fish warriors, protecting freedom and justice, or alternatively, at the helm of an all consuming army that encorporates the DNA of all the worlds most dangerous creatures and destroys all who stands in its way...

At least in the multiplayer, the singleplayer campaign is lacking in player-driven plot influence at all, but that's to be expected given the games age, RPG elements weren't common in RTS until recent years.

The gameplay is based largely around your ability to design your own units. You can mix any two creatures that are in the game, choose which parts of which you want to incorporate, and then send it into battle. Different creatures and in-turn different parts of creatures will have different costs. In the campaign you can design them on-the-fly, but in multiplayer you need to design your army beforehand, so having multiple sitting around is handy for properly expecting every map.

Pros:

Solid gameplay.

Price isn't bad at all.

Mod support, even if the workshop integration is very finicky.


Cons:

Steam port is a little buggy, especially around the workshop.

This game was made in 2003, it just simply isn't going to stack up to modern games in terms of graphics.

The availability of creatures is misleading, at least aesthetically. While you have a lot of animals to choose from, and it does in fact allow you to create very diverse armys, most of them look similar. By this I mean there probably almost a dozen big cat species, why. And almost every creature is a quadruped, excluding arthropods and snakes. The only bipeds are all birds, and they can't actually walk on their legs, even if you remove their wings, which means that aesthetically speaking, even with mods, you are going to be very limited in creature design.

It's a genuine shame that this premise never got followed up on. An RTS where you design all of your units, juggling cost, abilities, stats, and tech tier -- sometimes during battle -- could still revolutionize the genre.

IC isn't going to blow you away with its last-gen graphics or with its mediocre-to-moderate-good voiceacting and writing, but if you want to play something that's a bit different from your ususal Star Crafts and Gray Goos, IC is a very reasonably-priced shake-up in your gaming roster.

If you missed this back when it came out, if you enjoy retro-gaming, or if you just like RTS design theory, you could do a lot worse than spending a few hours whipping up some scorpionbears and lemmingskunks.

I played this game a lot quite a few years ago. I received the game from a friend way past what most would consider an 'expiration' date on games, back when I had dial-up internet (it still exists, people!) and not a whole lot of money to invest into gaming.

So when I think about this game, I'm not thinking of it through nostalgia goggles. I'm thinking of it among the greats of RTS games, like Age of Empires 2, Empire Earth, Command & Conquer: Generals, Warcraft 3, Starcraft, etc.

There's something extremely charming about this game. The characters are fun, the campaign missions can be very challenging, and the creature combinations range anywhere from hilarious to awesome. If you find the underlying flavor of the humor, characterizations, and voice acting to be enjoyable, then you'll have a ton of fun with this title. This is a unique title that hasn't had many elements from it continue on in the RTS titles since, which at once is both unfortunate for the RTS genre and quite fortunate from this title.

I definitely recommend this game.

26933319.review:
Impossible Creatures is easily one of my all-time favorite games. I've been playing it since it was first released, but there's plenty more to it than nostalgia.

Pros:
-Creature Customization: You can design a completely distinct army of up to nine combined creatures. These creatures can range from high-level tanks to flying units to fully aquatic units. The only limit to army design is your own creativity.
-Graphics: Even though the game released in the early 2000s the graphics still hold up reasonably well to this day. Yeah some of the designs may be blocky and the textures can look awkward, but considering the time it was made the graphics are pretty good.
-Balanced Combat: Unless you or your opponent have a very OP creature, combat is pretty balanced. You just have to be strategic in how you play the game.

Mixed:
-Campaign Play: The campaign story in the game is something I personally enjoy because of the nostalgia but it could be off-putting to some people. The characters are all interesting and the villains are intimidating (Dr. Ganglion comes to mind right away), but the campaign is very short, you can easily get through it in a few hours if you know what you're doing and the payoff at the end isn't as exciting as it was built up to be.
-Resource Management: The two resources in the game can be tricky to manage properly. Electricity is unlimited provided you have enough generators/lightening rods, but coal is finite and during the campaign once all the coal is used up there's no way to get any more. You can exchange electricity for coal in freeplay, but that still won't make up for mining. Resource attrition can be a useful strategy while playing but it can also be a huge annoyance.
-High Level Research and Creatures: Going along with the resource management issue is the problem of high-level resorces and creatures. While it's very useful it can easily drain you of coal and electricity. High-level creatures can easily drain your resources as well, a sperm whale x any level III or higher land animal will cost over 500 coal.

26495792.review:
Nunca habia oido hablar de IC hasta ahora, pero desearia haberlo conocido antes. 

Estamos ante un RTS increiblemente divertido, lleno de humor y muy rejugable. Es increiblemente facil de aprender (Solo hay 2 recursos que recojer y todos tienen las mismas mejoras y edificios), pero muy dificil de dominar (cada uno tendra un ejercito propio con habilidades muy diversas)

La creacion de animales es facil de usar, se basa en juntar 3 o mas partes (dependiendo del animal) de 2 animales, y dependiendo de la parte que sea esto cambiara el costo del animal,su forma de atacar (mordiendo, lanzando veneno...) ,sus habilidades (cavar, regenaración, camuflage, lanza telarañas...) y su forma de desplazamiento. Cada ejercito tiene 9 criaturas.
Los animales se ordenan en edades del 1 al 5 dependiedo de su fuerza,cuando juegas empiezas en el primer nivel cuanto mas rapido subas de nivel antes podras usar las criaturas tochas. La cantidad de posibilidades que ofrece el editor de criaturas es impresionante, y puedes tener incluso mas si le instalas mods.

IC tiene 3 modos de juego:
-Historia: Una campaña de 15 misiones con una historia interesante y llena de humor, en este modo empezaras sin animales y tendras que conseguirlos disparandoles dardos a animales salvajes para obtener su ADN. Cada vez que consigas el ADN de un animal nuevo te explicaran las mejores formas de combinarlo, cosa que biene muy bien. La campaña en general me a gustado pero tiene un par de cosas malas. Si la IA o tu os quedais sin carbon sera imposible avanzar y que en algunos mapas. Avanzar en un par de niveles se vuelve muy tedioso por la forma en la que esta hecho.
-Escaramuza: Elige un mapa,ejercito, IA o IAs enemigas,dificultad, modificalo la partida, y a destruir el laboratorio del enemigo. Hay muchos mapas y se puede jugar por equipos. La IA no es lo mejorcito, pero aun cumple. 
-Multijugador: Igual que el modo escaramuza pero ademas de con bots, con jugadores online, si juegas solo con gente puedes jugar a 2 modos de juego mas. Estos son: destruir todo lo que tenga el enemigo y cazar a Rex. En el modo cazar a Rex cada jugador tendra a Rex Chance como unidad que se regenera, envenena y dispara dardos y tiene que acabar con el rex enemigo.

El juego tambén incluye un editor de mapas para acerte mapas para cualquier modo y otro editor para crear mods principalmente animales nuevos, aunque esta herramienta es mucho mas dificiles de usar.

En muchas partidas te acaba sobrando mucha electricidad y apenas te queda carbon, pero eso se soluciona con la expansión Insect Invasion (que viene incluida), no tiene campaña pero mejora mucho el modo multijugador y escaramuza, con nuevos animales,nuevas tecnologias, nuevos mapas y mas usos de la electricidad, como transformarla en carbon o activar un modo de fuego especial en la torreta.

El modo historia esta bien, pero el modo multijugador y escaramuza seran a las que mas horas jueges. La cantidad de estrategias que puedes hacer es alucinante.

La version de steam viene con multijugador funcional, soporte para ordenadores modernos, la expansion, workshop, steam cloud y unas cuantas guias y entrevistas dentro de los archivos del juego.

También cabe destacar que el juego tiene un pequeño toque de humor que se agradece, entre las voces de los humanos y ver a Elefantesaraña peleandose con Tiburonesvoladores.

La musica del juego depende de el mapa en el que estes jugando (selva , hielo, pantando) y de el estado de la partida, si te atacan la musica cambiara a un tema mucho mas fuerte y animado, y si no pasa nada, cambiara a un tono mas relajado. Ademas de que la musica del menu es una obra maestra.

No todo es perfecto, tiene algun que otro error:
-Lo que e mencionado antes de la campaña, si te quedas sin carbón es muy dificil hacer nada
-La IA cumple pero puede volverse algo predecible
-Algunas combinaciones de animales son mucho mas buenas que otras, osea algun desbalanceo.
-Se echa de menos algun modo de juego extra a la hora de jugar el multijugador
-El numero de unidades maximo es algo bajo, solo puedes tener 75 unidades a la vez.
-Las alertas del juego cansan un poco, ya que hay muy pocas voces, oiras cientos de veces: !The creatures are under attack! 

A mi me a parecido un juegazo, una pena que lo conozca tan poca gente

Mi nota personal: Un 8,5

Por ultimo me gustaria recomendar un mod de la comunidad llamado Tellurian http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=655968653 que usa la expansion insect invasion y añade nuevos mapas, sube el maximo de unidades a 250, añade nuevos animales y balancea mejor las criaturas. Osea, soluciona muchos de los problemas del juego. Recomendadisimo

26114942.review:
Impossible Creatures ... ayant finit le jeu à l'époque de sa sortie, il y a de ça très longtemps, je l'ai reprit sur steam, craignant que comme habituellement, tout mes anciens jeux que je reprend sur steam soient ne se lancent pas soient ne sont pas FR. Quelle à donc été ma surprise de voir que non seulement il tourne impec sans bug et qu'en plus il était en  FR !

Franchement c'était une très agréable surprise. Voir qu'en plus le workshop fonctionnait avec ce jeu est une autre bonne surprise.

Bon il est vrai que j'ai eut pour ma part un bug assez chiant au tout début, ma faute puisque avant de lancer le jeu je suis d'abord passé par le configurateur, ce qui m'a créer un profil par défaut qui n'était pas reconnu par le jeu, une fois celui-ci effacé j'ai pu enfin créer mon profil directement via le jeu et gérer la config de celui-ci depuis le jeu et non pas grace a un autre programme.

Donc parlons du jeu, graphiquenent un peu dépassé mais pas spécialement moche, le jeu reste très simple dans sa prise en main, on est en terrain connu pour qui est habitué aux jeux de stratégie. 2 ressources à gérer plus une pop, simple c'est pas prise de tête.
La création de son armée se fait aux petits oignons. On trouve sur le terrain des animaux neutre sur lesquels on prélève l'adn que l'on utilisera après pour faire des mix entre deux espèces. Sympa, facile, le créateur d'armées permet de satisfaire à tout les assauts possible et imaginable.

Ce jeu était déjà à l'époque un très bon jeu de stratégie, et il l'est toujours autant aujourd'hui. 

Le doublage audio FR est parfois un peu mou, mais il n'en reste pas moins efficace.

Si je devais donner un point négatif c'est l'interface en elle même qui est trop présente à l'écran, prenant une bonne moitié de l'écran, c'est dommage.

Franchement je vous recommande ce jeu, il n'est pas cher, tourne sur n'importe quel pc, permet de passer plusieurs heures avant de le finir ... top :)

25688468.review:
Truly original and unique game, I had hours of fun with this as a kid and it's still great now. Perfecting an army of hybrid monsters is amazing fun and you'll be proud seeing your hard work march/crawl/fly/swim into battle. The level of tactical depth is an order of magnitude above most other RTS games not only do you use your units in the right way, but you can build them from the ground up to be what you need. I'd say there's a real art in creating a useful strategy (for example l3 meatshield +l2 range is a classic combo)- and a science to optimising your creations to be a cut above others (how do you get the best bang for your buck for a l3 tank creature).

Also some of the creature combinations are absolutely hilarious especially with the auto naming system. I think 'Komodo Drunk' has already been mentioned but a great one my friend came up with is the 'Sperming Whurtle'.

Overall great game and something totally unique- Hugely underrated and long overdue on steam.

Buy it especially if you like tinkering or being creative.

24063168.review:
Ahh, a game that brings back memories of many years of suffering and joy.  I've not yet put many hours into the steam version, but Impossible Creatures featured in the better part of my childhood and this version still holds up toit's past self (as I remember it).  It's not the most unique game now or the one with the best plot, sure, but it is one in which experimenting, with the slightly odd to the somewhat disturbed, down right crazy is not only fun but productive.  I've spent many hours before assembling the wonkiest creatures I could and sending them out to fight (often to great effect) and I plan to do so again.

So far, from what I've seen, this version is exactly the same as before, which is great, except for a few minor details I'd hoped would be fixed, when I'd heard this game was out: 

First and most minor, the black picture, When taking pictures of your creations in the old IC, sometimes the thumbnails would turn out black, especially if you moved the camera.  This could be fixed by taking lots of pictures, but you might not get that neat post you'd wanted.  Now if anything, this aspect seems a little worse than I remember.

Second, connection drops.  Now, I haven't tried ICO yet (odd bit of trouble with that, did IP connection instead), but when playing, at any point, start to end, you risk being dropped.  Kinda annoying at the start, REALLY annoying if you're about to win (it's not the other player's fault, happens when we fight computers together too).

Third, probably more a fault of my own than the creators.  Almost my games seem to come down to whoever get's the most coal fastest and overwhealms to enemy in one swift stroke, ending it quickly, or whoever runs out of coal last and picks off the remaining enemies dragging on and on.  It feels like there's no middle ground, no area control exchange, no games just long enough to comfortably slide into things but short enough not to get bored. 

That being said, this game is still one of my favourites, and will continue to be.  And is definitely worth getting on sale.

23961422.review:
[h1]Абсолютно уникальная RTS![/h1]

Не так та уж и просто создавать обзор на игру, которой стукнуло уже [b]более 10 лет[/b] (вышла на западе в 2002). 
Но всё же постараюсь.

Уникальной данной стратегии в реальном времени (RTS) в том, что мы можем создавать [b]абсолютно уникальную[/b] свою армию. [i]"Как мы это будем делать?"[/i] - спросите Вы, на что я отвечу:
[b] "Мы будем играть в безумного учёного, соединяя двух абсолютно разных животных".[/b] 

В этом и вся сладость игры - у нас есть 71 животное для комбинации. При этом мы можем изменять голову, туловище, передние и задние лапы и хвост (у летающих - и крылья). И всего этих комбинаций... [h1]127 392 ![/h1]

А каждая отдельная часть может нести за собой различные активные и пассивные умения. 
[i]Хвост дикобраза позволяет стрелять иглами, задние копыта барана дают эффект наскока, голова косатки - сонар, позволяющий смотреть маленькую часть карт и так далее...[/i]

Такого вы не увидите ни в одной игре!

[b]Плюсы:[/b]

[b]1. Сюжет[/b]
Очень нетипичный, но в то же время и интригующий. Количество злодеев и их помощников просто зашкаливает.
Спойлер: [spoiler]в конце нас ожидает прямая отсылка к "Кинг-конгу"[/spoiler]

[b]2. Графика[/b]
Это, конечно, не супер-графон, но как для игры 2002 года (и даже с улучшенной графикой) выглядит вполне неплохо. Да и вообще - это RTS! Зачем игроку смотреть на то, как ползают муравьи по густой траве?

[b]3. Механика и баланс[/b]
Хочешь сделать слабых разведчиков с большой дальностью зрения? Тогда ты сможешь тут же их создавать за сущие гроши. 
Хочешь создавать супертанки в стиле ОМАРОСЛОНА? Тогда, уважаемый, расплачивайтесь огромными затратами на улучшение и дорогой ценой существа. 
К тому же - каждая часть существа даёт свои плюсы и минусы. Плюс к здоровью и броне может повлиять минусом на скорость или увеличением цены.

Впрочем - кого создавать - решать Вам.

[b]4. Озвучка[/b]
Практически каждое существо - от хамелеона и до того же слона - было озвучено. Вот только при выборе существа звучит то существо, чья голова на этом химерном теле. И даже было выделено внимания таким мелким деталям, как беганье муравья по земле (если, конечно же, зумить на максимум прямо на этого муравьишку). Кстати, со всех существ по сюжету обнаружить муравья сложнее всего.

[b]5. Локализация. [/b]
И вот, после практически 10 лет простоя - игра получила русскую локализацию. В кое-то веки!

[b]6. Поддержка модов и редактор карт.[/b]
Мало тебе разнообразия игры? Можешь создать свою карту, своё существо, добавить свои фишки...

Не обошлось и без минусов:

[b]1. ИИ существ.[/b]
Старая ошибка старых RTS - если собрать 30 различных существ и послать их из точки А в точку Б, то все 30 существ будут идти по одной линии "паровозиком".

[b]2. Локализация.[/b]
Вот подумаем - что может быть плохого в нашей локализации? А то, что далеко не все дикторы перейнялись данным сюжетом, сценарием... Особенно раздражает голос "помощника". В английской версии это был толстый высокий мужичёк с нехилым басом, а что у нас... Полная дичь.
Хорошо, что хотя бы диктор местных жителей сделал своё дело на все 100%. 

И да - Рекс Ченс, а не Рекс Шенс.

[b]3. Пустой онлайн.[/b]
Вообще пустой. Только по локальной сети с другом да и то - нужно такого друга ещё найти. 

[b]97 / 100[/b]
[i]Разве я имею право судить воистину уникальную игру?[/i]

Степень хардкорности по версии Арея: [b]убитые 30 млн нервов.[/b]
Кто знает, как избавиться от братьев подручников Велики Ла Пет? Мало того, что у них армии дофига, так ещё мои ресурсы хотят стырить.

22767514.review:
Unzählige Stunden habe ich früher mit dem erschaffen und in die Schlacht hetzen diverser Kreaturen verbracht. Selbstredend darf auch hier ein Review nicht fehlen, zu sehr genoss ich damals wie auch heute das simple aber dennoch gut unterhaltende Spielprinzip, welches Impossible Creatures einizgartig macht;

- Viele Tiere bieten viele Möglichkeiten sie miteinander zu kombinieren
- Die Herausforderung der einzelnen Spiele (inklusive Kampagne) lässt sich jederzeit selbst manipulieren in dem Mann ganz bewusst auf gewisse Tiere verzichtet
- Die Gestaltung der Schauplätze, wo sich Ihre Kreaturen mit dennen des Gegners messen dürfen, sind unterhaltend unterschiedlich zu einander und keines plump daher programmiert
- Die Logik hinter den Werten sämtlicher Tiere und die der zuvor angesprochenen Karten ist mehr als aussreichend um sich in ein Spiel richtig hinein versetzen zu können

Summa summarum; Impossible Creatures ist ein Spiel, das Echtzeitstrategie wie auch lang erwartete Innovation im Spielebereich verknüpft. Mir ist bislang kein Spiel bekannt, welches die Möglichkeit bietet, jederzeit derart stark in dass gesammte Geschehen einzugreifen, in dem Mann (und auch Frau) seine herstellbaren Kampfeinheiten laufend abändert (wer mich eines besseren belehren kann - ich wäre Ihnen sehr verbunden!) und dennoch sehr ausgeglichen in der Spielweise bleibt. 
Manchmal ist neu nicht gerade besser, da meiner Meinung nach sehr viel Potenzial in diesem Spiel steckt, das heute noch nicht wirklich ernsthaft verfolgt wurde, um, beispielsweise, zumindest den Spielstiel in neueren RTS unter zu bringen.

Lets take a walk through time...
[h1]Pros[/h1]
-RTS (Real Time Strategy)

[h1]Veridict[/h1]
   Impossible Creatures ,along with two other RTS games, has been in my life since i could play a computer. This game always made me think about creating a new monster from two seperate creatures, Eagle and Bear? Why not! Ant and Orca? Go ahead! Impossible Creatures came out a LONG time ago, well not that long. 2003 to be Precise, and the graphics show as well. However the gameplay is my main concern here. Being able to create creatures by combining their positive adaptations within life, and ruleing out their cons, is fun; but commanding them to attack one another as if they were units of war, is a whole-nother story. Creatures can be created in the creature chamber and assigned to 'Armies' for use within battle. The Story is good, and the Characters have a good, vivid personality. Not into campaign? Well then Skirmish or Online (if its even still avaliable) are for you! Picking a map to fight on, send creations after anothers artocitys. It is truely fun, and the information given about each individual animal is HUGE, great for writing reports about. If you're looking for something to either, Play for the Creation, or for the Challenge, Impossible Creatures is definitly the Retro way to look.

22203008.review: A classic RTS game with an interesting twist of being able to design your own personal army of criss-cross creatures. The Steam version also includes the Bonus Animals expansion and Insect Invasion pack right off the bat, bringing the total amount of creatures to warp into chimeras from 50 to 75, halfway doubling the amount. Multiplayer is a bit tricky nowadays and it's a shame Relic hasn't considered giving IC a sequel after all these years. 22192022.review:
I saw this game years ago and thought it looked too "kiddie" for me.

But after reading other reviews and seeing the game's sense of humor I changed my mind and gave it a try.

The most fun is trying out different animal combinations for building armies.  Unlike every other RTS I've ever played, this one might have the highest replayability possible, because all the units are customized.  So rather than focusing on certain canned units like other RTS, it's hard to know if the units you've come up with are going to counter whatever someone else might throw at you.

The RTS has limited resources per map - so only so much coal will be available, although electricity can be converted into coal too.

The voice acting is fun and the learning curve keeps me coming back.  The UI is dated.  For example the ESC key is ignored and you have to hit the "menu" button instead.  I've only played a few hours and so far it's been worth the sale price of $2.99 for the game.  Looking forward to trying some multiplayer games too.

22132443.review:
Great game, bad Steam version.  

I played for two hours and encountered several glitches.  The game crashed once in the first hour (I never had it crash while playing the disc version for thousands of hours).  The unit icons in game often came up as completely black, which makes it difficult to see which unit you are creating and undercuts the point of a thought-based strategy game.  Furthermore, during the sixth mission the endgame trigger did not occur after completing all objectives.  Had to restart the entire mission.  All of this happened in not even two hours played (yes I got through that many missions in two hours because I'm a boss).  I expect there will be more glitches if I continue.  I asked for a refund.  These are not HUGE problems, and you will still be able to experience this fantastic game.  But this is clearly a sloppy port designed for quick profit and I refuse to support a publisher who does this.

I will keep looking for updates and will change my review if the developer fixes these issues.

EDIT:  Developer seems to be aware of issues and is updating the game.  Most recent update was March 30, just a day ago.  One of the improvements is "reduce the chance of glitch where game does not end after completing objectives."  Reduce?  How about fix?  Or how about not putting a game on Steam without having ironed out the bugs, especially if they are significant?

EDIT:  November 27 - Still no more updates

EDIT:  January 19 - Publisher seems to have abandoned this project.  Unfortunately, if you want to play IC this is the only decent option, besides tracking down a used copy somewhere.  Whether you want to support this kind of sloppy publishing is up to you.

21117176.review:
A clever and unique RTS, but falls far short of brilliant. It's basically a novelty, but one I wish someone would repeat and do better.

So let's talk about that uniqueness briefly:

You can combine TWO monsters. The size of the creature will be the size of the larger one. This dumbs down the creature building a lot, although some would argue that it adds complexity since you have to pay attention to sizes. The result is that I keep wanting to combine small creatures since they're cool (tiger racoon? skunk chameleon?), but because they're tiny, their stats suck. 
SO I end up making a couple "throw-away" lower tier creatures for defense, and focus on the huge tier-5 monsters, then I mass produce those. With the right combinations, the high stats outweigh almost any strategy. Yes, some combinations COULD be countered, but the AI certainly won't do it.

It also can become pretty challenging if skirmishing against hard or expert bots(they have all sorts of map hacks and are good at micromanagement). 20413680.review: Possibly one of the greatest RTS' of the early 2000's, I recommend this game to all players, new or old. As you can tell by the existing videos and images, you can create and combine dozens of animals together to create millions of creatures built for combat. Managing your resources to create these creatures is also important , as running out is sure fire to you losing. The game is centered around Rex Chance heading to a group of fictional islands in the South Pacific to find his missing father, Dr. Erik Chanikov. However, things take a turn for the worst when Rex meets Upton Julius, a wealthy madman who plans to use the Sigma Technology that Dr. Chanikov created to take over the world. Luckily, Rex meets Lucy Willing, Dr. Chanikov's right-hand assistant. Rex and Lucy work together to take down both Upton and his goons to find his father. As you play the campaign, you unlock more creatures, buildings, and abilities to use. (By abilities, I'm talking about the two main characters.) The game works around a level system. There are 5 levels, each one allows for stronger creatures than the last, and a few add buildings. Level 1 features basic creatures, while Level 5 can feature massive beasts to overwhelm the enemy. The game works extremely well, and they're even adding workshop support to allow hundreds of new maps and mods to be added to the game. At this point, Nordic said they might begin work on a sequel. Again, I recommend this game for all players, even if you don't like the RTS genre. It's a great place for beginners, and an amazing point for veterans. It's worth every penny put into it. I own the original disc copy from the old site Xplosion, but I'm glad this gem finally made it's way back. My friend's and I love it, and you all should too.

19888525.review:
[i]В очередной раз убеждаюсь, что современный игроконвеер, обладая огромными бюджетами в большинстве случаев не способен выпустить уникальный продукт, обойдясь, без очередной стратегии про роботов, нападение инопланетян, или третью мировую. Но то удалось Relic Intertaiment и Microsoft в далеком 2002 году. Через тринадцать лет он выпустили ремейк с поддержкой Full HD, всеми патчами и дополнением Insect Invasion, добавляющим новых существ в игру.[/i]

[b]В чем суть?[/b]
На остров в Тихом Океане закидывает военного журналиста Рекса Шанса и помощницу ученого Люси Уиллинг, которые, стремясь отомстить за смерть отца Рекса, встречают ожесточенное сопротивление оппортунистов в виде классических, но несколько необычных злодеев. По мере продвижения по сюжету, Рекс обретает новые способности и может помогать в бою своей армии.

Суть до боли проста, строить армию, планомерно унижать оппонента, вплоть до полного уничтожения его армии, строений и рабочих. Это есть во всех RTS, что же тут необычного? А необычное тут - существа составляющие вашу армию. Проект над которым работал отец Рекса позволял клонировать и скрещивать животных, в связи с чем нам придется делать что? Правильно! Скрещивать и клонировать! Армии состоят из девяти существ: каждое является комбинацией двух любых животных из 76, предоставляя нам 127 392 возможных комбинаций в целом. Многие из животных имеют врождённые способности и перки, добавляющие активные и пассивные умения. 

Действие происходит на островах, в разных климатических условиях: джунгли, пустыни, заснеженные равнины, Рексу придется путешествовать, собирать ДНК новых животных и скрещивать, скрещивать, скрещивать.

Хотите скрестить барана с жирафом? Пожалуйста, получится отличный живучий Жиран, обладающей защитной аурой в компании 4+ таких же, и с лобовой атакой рогами в 10 единиц, хотите скрестить угря и гориллу? Получится опасная тварь с ультиматичной сплеш-способностью электро-шока, который бьет и своих и чужих. Вариантов уйма, животным можно менять части тела, что влияет на характеристики и конечную стоимость. 

Так же в игре прикручен мультиплеер, и имеется небольшой онлайн, дающий надежду на сетевые баталии. 

Стоит ли брать игру тем кто в нее играл в детстве? Вы сами знаете ответ. Строит ли ее брать тем, кто в нее не играл? Однозначно, да! За 149р. рублей вы получите уйму удоволствия, где еще вы сможете скрестить жабу с гиеной и отправить ее в бой против отряда собакокитов. 

[b]Вердикт: 10 бабопардов из 10.[/b]

19454116.review:
In December of '02, while this game was being released in the States, as an Australasian I could only hear about the game which wasn't going to be released in Aussie and NZ until February '03. So, in December '02 I got in touch with Dick Smith and managed to reserve a copy. My first pre order.

[h1]AESTHETIC[/h1]
When the game was released, we had to buy a new PC to run it because not only was it one of the very first games able to run on DX9, it [i]required[/i] it to run smoothly and look gorgeous. And when I say gorgeous, I'm not kidding. The game still holds up its art style today and looks better than some new Steam releases out there. Inject ENBSeries (you're best with San Andreas 0.73) into this and if you're up to it see if you can't enhance the textures with Photoshop [b]and good lord in heaven is it [i]beautiful[/i][/b]. The soundtrack in this helps to bring the mood of the game out and I could easily listen to it outside of playing the game. The in-game sound effects are not only fitting tothe game's theme but each provide absolute clarity to the function or state of a unit or structure, while the general foley heightens immersion. To top it off, the noir inspired cutscenes and voice acting are intentionally cheesy, to the point where the initially irritating "The critters are under attack!" soundbite becomes endearing. It's a very pretty game whose visual and aural design has stood the test of time. 

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Gameplay itself is also [i]surprisingly[/i] well maintained: There was and still is almost no sign of glitching, and anything that does occur is insignificant or caused by third party mods. I think I even enjoyed one glitch that occurs so much that I'd rather a player discover it for themselves: [spoiler]combining some creatures results in their running animation speed up to like ten times the original[/spoiler]. Instead of the standard of using an intricate resource system and combining it with a simplistic preset army, there are only two (easily interchangable) resources and the way a player uses them is defined by how their army is not only produced but initially built: there are previously made creatures from some of the example armies and campaign character armies but the best way to have fun with this game is dive head first into its main feature: the creation of a unit by combining two animals and choosing its specialisation by selecting which physical segment of each creature the resulting amalgam receives. Each animal has a set of internal stats, abilities and physical attacks associated with each segment. A player must be cautious: they must balance cost with offensive capability, special abilities and various key points. The game even has an army analyser to help players create units that will tough it out, hopefully to victory. One of the game's protags says it best: balance is the key to versatility, and versatility will allow you to be prepared for anything. Sadly, I do have to say that Relic did a [i]very[/i] poor job with balancing, or at least overlooked the side effects that combination would have on balance. In an RTS game, it's possibly one of the worst things to be caught off guard by. Luckily, most mods fix this issue with ease.

[h1]CUSTOMISATION[/h1]
[b]Good lord[/b]. It's a shame that the game's source code was never released [i](hint hint)[/i]because it made modding particularly frustrating, especially when it caused modders to be forced to retexture and reshape the wolf unit in Blender so not to have too few or too many polygons, disallowed the ability to customise map flags, made creating campaigns particularly tiresome, and as a result putting a chokehold on the limits of the modding scene. In spite of this, the modding community have really outdone themselves and in spirit of the original dev team's demonstartion of pushing the framework beyond what was expected delivered one of the greatest and fun showcase of mods out there: Creature Chaos, Shadow, [i]Tellurian[/i], hell, even Invasion Of The Killer Ants smooth out a number of areas where gameplay is lacking. I personally feel that the game's small but hardcore fanbase would not have survived as long as it has without people like Revan, Doggiedoodle, Delirium, Puglin, and so many more incredibly dedicated players behind the game, pushing it to its limits. I for one would greatly enjoy seeing Workshop integration to see what fresh ideas a wider audience can bring to the table.

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
This game has stood the test of time. And for good reasons. I feel that had it not been for some unfortunate circumstances, it would be as recognised and celebrated as Age of Empires, Rise of Nations or Red Alert. It was and [i]still[/i] is worth the hundred bucks I paid for it almost thirteen years ago. I look forward to seeing it renewed by a fresh community, and wish for it to regrow above and beyond what it's ever been, because this game is simply one of the best Real Time Strategies available, and personally one of the best games I have ever played.

[h1]FINAL RATING: [b]8.5/10[/b][/h1]

19365356.review:
Don't mind my play counter. I used to play the original game a lot as a teenager.

Impossible Creatures is an RTS created by Relic Entertainment, the same company that produced the Warhammer 40K Dawn of War games, and later Company of Heroes. The main Gimmick here, however, is Steampunk mad scientist shenanigans.

Essentially, the game revolves around fusing different animals together (say a girrafe and a cobra, for example) to combine traits and strengths of different animals together. Each animal is put into a class from 1 to 5, one being least powerful, five being more powerful. The better and more powerful the animals are when they are combined, the higher class they become. However, you have to level up your base, and get new buildings in order to access level 5 animals, and the animals are also more resource intensive.

There is a campaign that slowly introduces the mechanics, while also telling a cheesy 1930's sci-fi story, but the meat of the game is the skirmish mode, single and multiplayer. When you start a game, you have to develop your army (or choose a prebuilt one) by combining two animals together, filling 9 slots, while balancing less powerful units with more powerful ones. From there, you play a fairly standard RTS game with resource gathering, micromanagement and battles. I'm not very good at RTS's so I can't comment on the AI, but I feel the gimmick and the gameplay is enough to make the game fun.

So yeah. It's a good game, not the best, but for $10 it's quite the steal.

19216701.review:
It's a brilliant RTS, designed around futuristic technology being researched during the 1930's. Imagine a world in which you're in control of combing the DNA of animals perfectly. You're able to reproduce the animal kingdom the way you see fit. The way you combine creatures give them powerful attributes, which could be used for good or evil.

  Keep in mind, this game was created many years ago. I truly believe this game had the potential to reach League of Legends and DOTA 2s caliber. It was an original RTS with online gameplay which players enjoyed tremendously. There are two major reasons the original release of this game failed.

1.) The developer and published had a legal dispute over another situation. They never worked with each other again, although Impossible Creatures 2 was in development phase. Due to their falling out, everything about IC was put on hold. It was no longer updated nor maintained. Eventually the online server was taken down. The community had some amazing people in it. Many people worked together to keep the game alive. There are some people who developed amazing mods for the game. The mods balanced out the game, created new content, and kept people playing through Hamachi.

2.) The game had limited advertising on release. They didn’t advertise this game nearly enough. It had thousands of players to begin with, but it slowly died off without people being aware of its existence.

  If you’re looking for an incredibly fun multiplayer RTS game, with unlimited possibility for strategic gameplay and skill. Look no further. This game will test your mind with rough competition online.

These ratings are based on steam release, not the original release.

Balance: 5 (Fixed with the proper mods)
Graphics: 5
Music: 4
Cinematics: 7
Story: 7
Content: 5
Controls: 9
Gameplay: 10

[b]Overall: 6.5[/b]

19145484.review:
I remember playing this game so much when I was younger, but unfortunaletly my childhood friend owned the disc copy and I haven't seen him in..years. To this day it remains the only RTS I have ever enjoyed.

Impossible Creatures has pre-battle strategy where you make your own army out of combined creatures. Maybe you'll fuse a sperm whale with an anteater to create a humongous blubber-lickinglicking "Sperm Ea... hmm Perhaps you combine a Black Widow spider with a Mountain Lion to create a Black Coug... the point is, all creatures have their strengths and weaknesses, defined by their health, defense, speed (land, sea &/or air), sight, size, coal/electricity cost, tier level and body part-specific abilities. The possibilities are endless. You could create a hideous tier 1 abomination only costing 50 coal, but it ain't exactly gonna be good. Instead, you could combine an anaconda with a dragonfly to make a giant flying tier 5 hugger of death with insane strength and bonuses, but it ain't exactly gonna be cheap.

In battle, you gather resources, build buildings to spawn your lovingly made creatures, construct defensive structures, buff structures, expensively upgrade your tier level instead of building defense and get rushed by better players etc. trying to murder death kill your opponent(s). Pretty standard stuff. But fun.

The campaign is hilariously over-the-top cheesy 40s-50s steampunk mad science adventure over 15-ish missions which go from easy to insanely hard really. really fast. Mostly because you don't have access to all your creatures, but have to gather them across all levels.

This game comes with the Insect Invasion expansion, which adds creatures with more niche and micro-management heavy abilities, so it's all good.

Sounds like a plan. I'm on it.

19131320.review:
"Held up surprisingly well"

Like world of warcraft, Impossible creatures opts for a simplistic, artsy graphical approach that lets this old school RTS still feel decent in that department. Although the RTS portion has all of the usual components (two resources, mine one, auto-mine the other, build up armies, attack/win), it's the ability to create your own units that really sets this game apart from anything else. With excellent free community mods, you receve around 70 creatures to mix and match the parts of. Resulting units change in cost, special abilities, and stats as appropriate - so building a team of 9 of these units that suits your playstyle then testing your composition out on the RTS battlefield is what this one is all about. 

There's still nothing else like it, so it's easy to recommend if you've been looking for an RTS that dares to do something a bit different.

19126512.review:
Oh boy, where to start...

This game is -very- fun. Not just saying that due to the nostalgia value of remembering when I was a wee laddy, peeking over my dad's desk watching him play this on his computer. No, unlike many other memories of my childhood, this game withstood the test of time and is actually [b]good[/b]. What makes it so good? It's main pull, gimmick, and attraction: combining creatures to make specific units with various abilities.

The pull of this game is its freeform army builder. The builder allows you to construct 9 units by mix-and-matching various body parts and pieces from two different animals to create a whole new unit. It's an incredible simple system that actually has quite a lot of meaning and strategy built in. Almost every part you swap; torso, head, front legs, back legs, etc, has some sort of statistical affect or grants a new ability. Simply changing one part can change the creature's role in a drastic way. And the best part? That creature's role is entirely up to you. You can make an army suited to your turtling playstyle. Or an army filled with fast, aggressive creatures designed for hit and run tactics. It's completely up to you.

The level of strategy in this game is deceptively deep. While on the outside someone might assume the game is fairly cut and dry; make creatures and throw 'em at each other, Impossible Creatures will surprise you with a hidden level of strategy. Where it differs from most RTS games is not only do you not know what your enemy might be doing, you dont even have a clue what his units even [i]are[/i]. Is he going to be using Stealth? Maybe burrowing? Does he have amphibious units? Are his creatures mainly melee? Or are they ranged? You may have built an army of massive powerhouses only to find that you forgot to give any of them Immunity. And sure enough, here comes your enemy with an army chock-full of poisonous beasties.

The campaign? It's not terrible, and I liked it, but some may not share the same sentiment. Impossible Creatures in general has a very diesel/steampunk feel to it which I absolutely adored and believe contributed to the game's unique success in a way. The game makes up for it with an engaging army builder that you can spend literal hours in making your army juuuuuust right, and a skirmish mode which you can face down bots and the like to practice your skills and test your army. With the Steam Version, Multiplayer is back and alive and from the few times I've been on, it seems to have a decent playerbase. Despite being made in the early 2000's, the game still looks very good.

All in all, for $10, it's completely worth it. Grab it, play it, have some fun with it.

Esto es una verdadera joya de estrategia en tiempo real de aquella época (el 2002, cómo pasa el tiempo!) pero con un toque magistral y único: aquí no hay unidades predefinidas, sino que las crearás tú combinando partes de animales como si de un Frankenstein Zoológico se tratara.

Combina en el laboratorio el bicho más feo que se te ocurra y luego crea ejércitos de ellos para atacar al enemigo (que, por supuesto, también lanza sus bichejos contra tí)

Por lo demás, es un RTS clásico de recolección de recursos, creación de una base y a machacar al enemigo misión tras misión (isla tras isla, en este juego)

Los gráficos han aguantado el paso del tiempo con gracia, aunque esas montañas con picos extraños en el paisaje te recuerden a otro tiempo glorioso en el que todos parecían mejores juegos que los de ahora xD

La música no sólo acompaña, sino que da gusto dejarla puesta. Se me han empañado los ojos al volver a oir la del menú, creo que se me ha metido algo dentro...

Los controles no necesitan presentación: botón izquierdo para seleccionar, botón izquierdo y arrastrar para selección múltiple, botón izquierdo para atacar...más clásico y sencillo, imposible.

He probado a ir alternando del juego normal al dlc dentro del menú y todo va de perlas. Sin problemas tampoco para ejecutarlo y me he hecho el tutorial de un tirón para probarlo todo y va de fábula.

He leído que a algunas personas les da un error justo al darle al botón de salir al escritorio, pero a mi no me ha pasado (lo he hecho 5 veces seguidas sólo para poder escribir esto). Lo único que sí he notado es que la barra de herramientas se me ha quedado tonta y no se oculta automáticamente, sospecho que algún proceso se queda atontado por ahí de fondo al ejecutar el juego. Una vez que he acabado de jugar, he tenido que cerrar el proceso explorer.exe y abrirlo de nuevo para solucionarlo. Aparte de esa tontería, ni un solo problema.

Resumen: Si no te importa jugar a algo con gráficos de aquella época (estilo Jedi Outcast, por ejemplo) y te van los RTS clásicos, esto es una verdadera maravilla. Además, estando en la oferta de salida, me ha costado menos de 6 euros. No se puede pedir más. Una joya.

One of my favorite video games across all genres, Impossible Creatures is an amazingly creative RTS. The ability to customize your units adds another level of strategy to the game. Do you want a wolf with the head of a chameleon? Done. Great white and a tiger? Easy. Flying monkeys? Why not?
The campaign is also enjoyable, and gradually unlocking creatures forces the player to experiment with their army, which in my opinion is a good thing.  
Of course, the game is not without fault. 9 creatures can be a bit limiting if you want an army that is strong at all stages of the game. Pathing can be a little buggy, and can (and WILL) mess up your creatures' positions (ranged units in front, melee in back, that kind of thing).
Overall, though, I give this game a solid 9/10. It has definitely aged well for a 13 year old game. Definitely pick it up if you enjoy RTS games.

19037096.review:
Impossible Creatures magically recreates my youth in 1930s Nebraska. From the cheetahs with lobster claws to the chimpanzees with lobster claws, everything I remember about lobster claws is there. In fact, it includes many animals I didn't realize had no lobster claws. I know some of my childhood friends (who had no lobster claws themselves) traded rumors about hammerhead sharks without lobster claws, but all the hammerheads I saw from my beach villa had lobster claws. The musk oxen grazing along the beach didn't have lobster claws, thankfully -- otherwise we'd have needed to reinforce all our homes with lobster claws cast in gold. Musk oxen were always charging buildings, but they didn't cause much harm because they didn't have lobster claws, which greatly increase the damage inflicted on buildings. Getting back to hammerhead sharks, I learned that they sometimes possess primate forelimbs (in lieu of lobster claws), and they can hurl small rocks a considerable distance. Despite their excellent vision radius, the giraffes with lobster claws were never able to throw things very well because lobster claws are not suited to ballistic activity. Speaking of giraffes, if you ever come across one with a lupine torso, don't bother running. It's got crazy endurance and will be in tip-top shape when you're panting and wheezing and collapsed on the ground. Even though it has no lobster claws, the giraffe can easily stomp you with its hooves or maul you with its non-lobster claws. Be very careful around giraffes, their appetite for the flesh of creatures without lobster claws is insatiable. Unless you have lobster claws yourself, then you're probably safe.

In short, all my lobster claw nostalgia is satisfied with this lobster claw simulator.

FULL DISCLOSURE: I don't have lobster claws.
