19030783.review:
First of all, I'm biased-- I'm one of those strange and twisted folk who kept playing this game after its original release fell into obscurity, and for years now the Impossible Creatures community has been fluctuating with an average of a dozen or so people at any given time, worldwide. But then, one day, Nordic Games approached us few survivors and told us of their plan to re-release the game on Steam; we jumped onboard as beta testers, and the day has finally come for release!

So yes-- basically, I'm not the most impartial of sources. But it's important for me to point out that Nordic has in no way asked or cajoled me to provide this review, nor have they had any input into its content. I'm just a fan of the game. In fact, I know the game inside and out, and that's why you should listen when I say: holy shit, Impossible Creatures is amazing.

Look, let's get the honest criticism out of the way early on-- this game came out in the very early 2000's. It does not look like Skyrim. The models are fairly low-detail (watch the trailer and look at the screenshots) and a lot of the gameplay elements-- build gatherers, gather resources, build buildings, tech up-- won't blow anyone's mind in a modern context. But that's not why this game is important; it's important because of its quirky, brilliant central idea-- its gimmick, if you will. Because as you no doubt have already noticed, Impossible Creatures gives you the ability to send into battle units of your own creation-- magnificent (or hilarious, or both) mixtures of stock animals combined to most efficiently wreak havoc on your opponent. And that's obviously where the game shines.

Don't get me wrong-- other parts of IC are phenomenal. For instance, the lush, beautifully painted maps, or the tactile, atmospheric soundtrack; all symptoms of a sumptuous, absorbing and vibrant style that has sadly gone out of fashion. This isn't the kind of game that strives to be edgy and dark; rather, it presents an experience you can actually enjoy, visually, audibly and emotionally. But the main reason you should buy Impossible Creatures is its depth of gameplay. The depth to this game is remarkable. That's why my people and I have been playing it for [commence italics] thirteen years [end italics]. Do you want to sneak into an enemy base and disrupt his resource gathering? Heck yes, son, chameleons crossed with cheetahs. Is there a mob of power-melee units trampling towards your coal mine? Mix some dragonflies with sharks and rain toothy hell on them from above. Perhaps you're the kind of strategist who prefers to turtle? Well, you're in luck! You can do that! Literally! With turtles! Or, hey, screw it-- if you prefer a more direct approach, why not just crush your opponents with a horde of elephants waving lobster claws? So with this in mind, there's obviously a huge scope for a variety of exotic and wonderful strategies-- and all of them can be successful, if you make good enough creatures and play with enough skill. If you have a playstyle, you can make it work. But this is all macro stuff.

It's the finer details that really make the game stand out. Even within overarching strategies there is an almost infinite scope for variation. For example, a fairly standard addition to any army is a level 3 melee unit-- a standard, versatile, mid-level grunt. But it's not like there's only one level 3 melee unit. Maybe you want something fast and poisonous, to inflict stings or bites and then retreat to a safe distance while the venom deals damage over time? Maybe you want something tough and powerful that forms herds and regenerates its health? Maybe your opponent crushed you last game with low-damage, high-health units en masse-- well, you can take a jaunt to the army builder and cook up something to deal with that; combine a wasp with a lioness and assassinate those meatshields into oblivion! 

This variation on a fine, precise level is what turns Impossible Creatures into an art form. It's baffling just what people come up with-- and phenomenal to see it work for them. A friend of mine named Matt, for instance, once fielded a musk ox with the head of a condor. It didn't have wings, just a condor head sticking out the front of this beefy ox body. It was called "accept me as your king", and we all thought it was hilarious, because it was.

Then it won a battle. Then it won another battle. Then Matt won the game. 

The combination of musk ox defense and cheap, large, low-melee condor parts just happened to result in a strangely optimal creature-- it was cheap enough that Matt could spam it, but tough enough to hold its own. This is why you should play IC; just when you think you've seen it all, a new strategy comes along that completely switches the metagame.

But, naturally, even a game as diverse and clever as Impossible Creatures has gameplay issues. Mostly these relate to balance. Sadly, when Relic stopped supporting IC, it wasn't perfect (nor can it ever really be). As it stands, the base IC package includes the Insect Invasion mod-- Relic's last attempt at balancing the game (which adds a lot of very fun and interesting mechanics). II was released an incredibly long time ago-- long enough that players have been able to essentially solve the game, and find the truly optimal combination of creatures to use in any given situation. Suddenly, all the depth and variety in the game began to disappear. Which is why myself, Matt, Steve, Phil and Byam-- the original core modding team-- decided to make an add-on mod for IC called Tellurian. 

Since we started, we've added 20 stock creatures to the game. It's the only mod still being maintained, balanced, and patched (as a matter of fact, 2.03 is almost ready for release). It's free (not for profit!), it's fun, and it comes with a bunch of maps-- so if you ever get tired of moose lobsters and baboon sperm whales at level 5 (spoilers), visit this page:

http://www.moddb.com/mods/tellurian/

... And try out giant squids crossed with panthers. Or blue whales crossed with scorpions. Or pistol shrimp horses-- just get the mod, you'll love it, and every download is a little more incentive to keep the project alive. 

Impossible Creatures lives anew-- buy it, download it! And let's be honest, for its incredibly reasonable price, even if you hate the gameplay you can still get your money's worth making daffy combinations in the army builder (yes, I know, komodo dragon crossed with a skunk becomes a "komodo drunk", everybody finds that one eventually).

19030093.review:
Barring a few blocky character models, this game has aged remarkably well and has such a great use of colour and style that it's still a joy to look at today. The soundtrack is mostly atmospheric but adds so much to the charm of the game.

It's fairly standard RTS fare but for the ability to create your own armies - you may take parts from two of the many stock animals to create a combined creature, and then take nine of these combined creatures into any game you play. The range of strategies is far more impressive than I think the developers could ever have hoped for, with creatures of various sizes, stats and abilities available to each player.

The only downsides I found with the original game were with the balance - some creatures are inherently better when combined with certain stock animals, thus making others effectively redundant but for their novelty value. In the past few years this has been addressed by player-made mods such as Tellurian, which also adds a range of new creatures to play with. It's nice to see that these mods are still compatible with the Steam edition.

All in all, I reccommend this :D

EDIT: I've nominated this for the Steam "Test of Time" award!

19024673.review:
10/10

I too, consider this game my childhood. I too, have clocked in over 1000 hours prior to the steam release. 

Let me tell you about this amazing game, Impossible Creatures.

[b]Campaign[/b]
[list]
[*] Fairly intriguing story for an old RTS
[*] Good progression, although difficulty ramps up fairly quickly for newbies
[*] Memorable characters 
[*] Decent length, depends on player skill
[*] No difficulty slider however

[/list]

[b] Creature Combining[/b]

I've been playing this game for a long, long time, and I still find new interesting combinations. The standard game has 50 stock animals, and with Insect Invasion, 10 bonus animals and the Tellurian mod this brings it up to about 95 creatures you can combine. And this isn't just straight up hybrids, oh no - you can choose exactly which body parts are from which animal. That's a lot of possible combinations.

Some things to note about this style of RTS and unit creation

 [list]
[*] Holy f*cking variety! You can make very varied armies (of 9 combined creatures) which are still viable in multiplayer
[*] Meta isn't as set in stone, there's counters for pretty much everything, naturally.
[*] Creatures have special abilities - such as electric burst with the eel, or camouflage with the chameleon. 
[*] Totally messed up and funny combinations can sometimes be pretty good
[*] You can name your own creatures
[*] Komodo Dragon + Skunk = Komodo Drunk :)
[/list]


[b] Multiplayer[/b]

Inevitably, the thing that'll keep you coming back is the multiplayer. Now, back when this was my childhood, I mainly stuck to Player vs Computer, but having played a fair bit of multiplayer now I can tell you it's really damn fun.

[list]
[*] Up to 6 players, free for all, teams or various game modes
[*] AI isn't half bad for an old game
[*] Absolutely insane battles with 6 players on large maps
[*] Games may range from 30 minutes - 4 hours (cough, Bikini Atoll, cough)
[*] Custom maps, mods (get Tellurian!) = Massive replayability
[*] Quite fast paced, something of a skill ramp but not crazy like Starcraft. Casuals will still have fun games with other casuals.
[/list]


[b] RTS Elements[/b]
It's still your standard RTS fair, except making your own units is the big awesome part of it.

[list]
[*] Two resources: Coal and Electricity. Getting a steady supply and managing resources is key.
[*] Expand with Workshops to other parts of the map, upgrade worker henchmen with Research Clinic and improve your creatures' stats with the Genetic Amplifier
[*] Higher level creatures (Levels range from I -> V) require research at your Lab (home base)
[*] Units may be land, water, amphibious or flyers
[*] Creature combinations will generally be either Melee or Range, but special abilities mix it up a bit
[*] You want to research up to higher level creatures ASAP, and have your army balanced so you can ward off rushes at earlier levels
[*] Defensive structures: Soundbeam towers for land creatures and Anti-Air towers for flyers
[*] Gyrocopter! 
[/list]

Tl;Dr: Awesome game, RTS lovers or even casuals will have a good time. You won't regret buying this!

19019143.review:
Un classique ressuscité par Steam ! Voici un formidable RTS de 2003 (hé oui, cela date !) dans lequel vous créez votre propre composition à partir de mutations génétiques. A vous de créer une armée équilibrée, basée sur le early ou late game, aérienne, forte au corps à corps… tout est possible ! Et surtout quelle joie d’affronter des joueurs aux armées farfelues, bien pensées, avec des mutations que l’on n’avait pas imaginé. Parfois on se marre à voir des armées complètement What the fuck des adversaires ! Si vous ne savez pas ce qui pêche dans votre armée, un outil vous permet d’analyser les forces et faiblesses de votre armée. Libre à vous de le suivre ou non.

Vous pouvez choisir deux animaux pour vos mutations. Ensuite, la liberté vous est offerte. Le corps d’un rhinocéros avec les pattes avant d’une mante religieuse ? Possible. Le corps et la tête d’une veuve noire accouplée à un dard et aux ailes d’un frelon ? Oui ! Et que pensez-vous d’un Croco blanc (crocodile + requin blanc) ? 

Pour le reste, ce sont les principes de base d’un RTS : deux ressources, des endroits où il va falloir batailler pour prendre l’avantage. Le jeu reste simple mais il va falloir bien penser son armée. Que faire lorsque l’on n’a aucune créature amphibie ou sous-marine ? Est-ce que je dois axer ma puissance sur l’early ou le late game ? Dois-je opter pour des grosses créatures tenaces ou des créatures rapides qui attaquent à distance ? A vous de voir. Vous avez 8 slots pour combiner les différents animaux présents. Et pour vous aider dans cette tâche, vous avez la possibilité de trier le bestiaire selon qu’elles soient résistantes, forte au corps à corps, qu’elles disposent d’une bonne vision, etc… De même, chaque animal possède de compétences propres (bonus en attaque en solitaire, en groupe, possibilité de bondir sur les créatures ennemies, etc…). Bien évidemment, plus la créature est puissante, plus elle requiert de ressources.

En bref, vous êtes face à une vraie perle que tout amateur de RTS se doit d’avoir ! Un grand merci à Steam de permettre à tous les anciens et aux nouveaux de rejouer à ce bijou !

[ENG]
You must buy this game if you are a true RTS fan.

[FR]
Je fais un peu plus long, je suis nul en anglais de toute façon.
J'ai ÉNORMÉMENT joué à ce jeu lorsque j'étais plus jeune, c'est CE jeu qui m'a fait aimer les RTS (les jeux de stratégie en temps réel, style Dawn of War ou Starcraft).
Si vous aimer les RTS, c'est l'un des meilleurs à mon goût, il a malheureusement énormément vieillit, mais faut voir aussi que le jeu date de presque 13 ans ! 
Bref, parlons un peu du jeu : 
Un RTS très complet, vous jouez le rôle de Rex Chance, un journaliste de guerre recherchant son père, un savant "fou" ayant été kidnappé par son ex-collaborateur dans des îles du pacifique. L'histoire se passe dans les années 1930.
Une fois en jeu, vous devrez récolter l'ADN des créatures sauvage avec votre fusil, vous pourrez ainsi combiner l'ADN de deux créatures différente pour en faire une nouvelle, ayant un mélange de caractéristique et de compétence.
Il faut également gérer deux ressources (comme dans la plupart des RTS) : le charbon et l'électricité. Pour ce faire, vous devrez "créer" des hommes de main pour faire ce boulot. 
Ces hommes de main vous serviront également à réparer votre base si elle se fait attaquer par l'ennemi et agrandir cette même base en fabriquant différent bâtiments. 

La campagne est plutôt dure mais relativement courte (une grosse dizaine d'heure en jouant bien je pense), il est possible de jouer contre l'ordinateur en dehors de la campagne, et logiquement, de jouer en ligne (je n'ai pas testé cette option sur Steam pour le moment).

Bref, je vous conseille énormément ce jeu, même si vous n'aimez pas les RTS, il reste très accessible. 

PS : le jeu fonctionne super bien sous Windows 10 x64

19013753.review:
Yes. Most definitely yes. This is the game that introduced me to the RTS genre. Heck, it introduced me to the world of video games. I had no idea what was waiting for me. Countless hours creating army after army, attempting to beat the hardest AI.Playing the Campaign.Playing Multiplayer, with what was left of the community.It all has been time i couldn't have spent better elsewhere. And I'm glad i didn't. Seeing IC come back from the dead like this... TO STEAM NO LESS. I just can't wrap my head around this.
Now, for the actual review:

Things and points I like most about the game:

1. It is fun. Every feature of the game is. From playing the campaign, all the way to making your own custom army that you then take onto the battlefield!!! Insert 300 reference here.

2. It is creative. I think the whole over 50.000 possible combinations and the presence of a level editor say everything.

3.It is challenging. Boy this one is so true. Especially if you are playing multiplayer. THERE IS NO MERCY ON THE FIGHTING GROUND. IN THIS GAME YOU EITHER WRECK FACE OR GET YOUR FACE REKT. Well...
you know...
it depends on who you're up against.Either way, before you hop into online play, it's best that you know how to play the game the slightest bit. Preferably play the tutorial.
Sorry if I misspelled anything. ^_^

NOW, FOR THE RATINGS. (Man this is long. You still with me? Hold on just a little longer.)

[b] Graphics = 9 [/b]
Before you go and tell everybody that the graphics suck, just take in consideration the year this game was made. This was revolutionary back then! Sometimes small glitches happen but very solid nonetheless. 

[b] Music = 8 [/b]
The soundtracks differ in every map type (Savannah, Jungle, Desert, Artic...).They are good. Nothing else to say here. Move on.

[b] Creativity / Originality = 10 [/b]
You can slap wings on a snake.

[b] Story = 7 [/b]
I personally didn't like the story that much : P . Multiplayer, army making and skirmishes agaisnt the AI make up for it.

[b] Gameplay = 10 [/b]
The Multiplayer matches can be either fast-paced or slow-paced. There is no way to tell what kind of creature combinations your enemy has got in their armies, so it really depends on the game style of the players. A lot of maps that further increase the diversity of the games. They are either ground based maps, or water based maps. (Could be a mix of both too).

[b] Overall = 9 [/b]

All this being said, this game is a must-have for every person out there that likes a very good Real-Time Strategy game.
